content.text:
# Draft:Schwarzmooskogel cave system

The Schwarzmooskogel cave system is the second longest cave in Austria. It is located in the Styrian part of the Totes Gebirge mountain range in the Loser area near Altaussee.
Exploration history
The Schwarzmooskogel ice cave was discovered in 1929 by researchers from Aussee, and exploration began in 1938. The Stellerweg Cave was discovered in 1940 and surveyed from 1953 onwards.
In 1976, members of the Cambridge University Caving Club (CUCC) began their research and in 1980 discovered the Schnellzug Cave and the Schwabenschacht, which they surveyed in the following years together with members of the Arbeitsgemeinschaft Höhle und Karst Grabenstetten e. V. (ArGe).
In 1983, speleologists from the Forschungsgruppe Höhle und Karst Franken e. V. (FHKF) in Nuremberg and the Verein für Höhlenkunde in München e. V. (VHM) discovered one of the largest ice-filled chambers in Europe: The Schneevulkanhalle (snow volcano hall), which is approximately 130 meters long, 90 meters wide, and up to 60 meters high, features a snow cone approximately 50 meters high, ice stalagmites 15 meters high, and icicles up to 10 meters long.
CUCC and ArGe continue to organize expeditions to this day, and over the years, additional caves have been discovered and connected to the cave system, like Steinbrücken Cave.
Dimensions of the cave system
This giant cave system consists of 17 individual caves and has been measured to a length of over 137 km (as of December 2024), making it the second longest cave in Austria.
The total depth is 1111 meters (as of December 2024).
See Also
* Steinbr%C3%BCcken Cave
* Sch%C3%B6nberg Cave System
